items.title: About me
items.description:
Hi! My name is Nick Webb.

I am an eLearning developer with almost 20-years experience. For the past three years I have been working with xAPI and the Adapt framework and authoring tool in my roles with International Workplace.

I have been instrumental in the company's adoption of Adapt. I have also been the lead developer behind most of our bespoke themes, components and extensions, including our xAPI extension.

content.title: HTML
content.body:
HyperText Markup Langage, commonly referred to as HTML, is the standard markup language used to create web pages. Along with Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) and JavaScript, HTML is a cornerstone technology used by most websites to create visually engaging web pages, user interfaces for web applications, and user interfaces for many mobile applications.

The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) recommends several conventions to ensure an easy migration between HTML and XHTML (Extensible HyperText Markup Language) (see HTML Compatibility Guidelines). The following steps can be applied to XHMTL 1.0 documents only:

  1. Include both xml:lang and lang attributes on any elements assigning language.
  2. Use the empty-element syntax only for elements specified as empty in HTML.
  3. Include an extra space in emptyâ€“element tags: for example <br /> instead of <br/>.
  4. Include explicit close tags for elements that permit content but are left empty (for example, <div></div>, not <div />).
  5. Omit the XML declaration.

HTML5 is a markup language used for structuring and presenting content on the World Wide Web. It was finalized and published on 28 October 2014 by the W3C. This is the fifth revision of the HTML standard since the inception of the World Wide Web.

tasks.title: Submitting your test
tasks.description:
If you have experience with, or are able to use Git, create your repository now, initialise this folder and push up your first commit.

Submitting your test via a GitHub or Bitbucket repository is preferred, but if you are unsure then simply ZIP up this folder once you are done and send it by email.
tasks.instruction: Try to make a commit after each task.

tasks.title: Your name
tasks.description: After familiarising yourself with the code used in this test, add your name to the header of this page using the app/data/content.json file.

tasks.title: Edit content
tasks.description:
Change the title in the header to:

Sponge UK Developer Test
tasks.instruction: Pay close attention to the italicised text.

tasks.title: Replace content
tasks.description: Replace the main content of this page (the "content" property of app/data/content.json) with the text found in resources/text-from-client.docx.
tasks.instruction: Pay close attention to any formatting and structure and try to normalise the styles. Correct any mistakes as you see fit.

tasks.title: Add content
tasks.description:
Before the #content block, add either an accordion or tabs element without using a pre-written plugin or library and add the sections:

  1. About me: A short paragraph about yourself
  2. Photo: A photo or avatar of yourself
  3. Links: Links to any sites that you have worked on or are particularly proud of with a small description of the role you played in their creation

tasks.title: Modify your new content
tasks.description: Update your element from the previous task to use a Handlebars template be populated from content that you add to the app/data/content.json file.

tasks.title: Simplify JavaScript
tasks.description: Simplify the JS in app/js/spongetest.js, making reusable functions. If you feel confident that the code is reusable enough, you can try moving the necessary content population code to the ContentInstance object in the app/js/lib/content.js file instead.
tasks.instruction: Include error handling to ensure the functions run even when passed invalid parameters.

tasks.title: Convert the CSS to LESS or SASS
tasks.description:
Take the CSS in the file app/css/spongetest.css and convert it to LESS or SASS.

Use variables for any colours so that they may be changed easily.
tasks.instruction: Don't forget to submit your raw .sass or .less file(s).

tasks.title: CSS boxes
tasks.description:
Without changing the HTML, use CSS to style the #boxes element to match the reference images as closely as possible.

In Chrome's Developer Tools, you can change your viewport to match exact screen widths given in the reference images.

The specifications for the boxes are as follows:

  • Don't change the padding on the #boxes element
  • Don't overwrite the background colours
  • The right (pink) box should always remain square and be 50% of the remaining width of the #boxes element
  • The left (yellow) box should be 50px high and 210px wide (but no wider than 50% of the remaining width of the #boxes element)
  • The font size for the text is 1.5em
  • The solution should work in all modern browsers and as far back as IE9

tasks.title: Task runner
tasks.description: Install and configure a Node task runner such as Gulp or Grunt and configure it to build your SASS or LESS files into .css files. Make a module with a package.json file and include your dependencies in there.
tasks.instruction: Please submit your package.json file so that we can install your environment but don't submit the node_modules folder — because it will be huge! Add the node_modules folder to the .gitignore list.

tasks.title: Rewrite JavaScript
tasks.description:
Rewrite app/js/lib/content.js, making it into an ES6 class.

Use the import statement to include the ContentInstance class from app/js/lib/content.js into app/js/spongetest.js
tasks.instruction: This will currently only work in the latest Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari and Opera — this is fine.

tasks.title: Responsive font size
tasks.description: Using the least amount of CSS possible and leveraging the existing font-size inheritance, increase the size of the font throughout the entire page to 125% of its current size when viewing the page in a window smaller than 500px wide.

tasks.title: Transpile JavaScript
tasks.description: Using a compiler such as Babel and your task runner from earlier on, make a task that transpiles the ES6 code from the "Rewrite JavaScript" task into ES5/ES2015.
tasks.instruction: Remember to submit your gulpfile.js or gruntfile.js as well as your package.json.
